journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Robust fault detection and isolation of hybrid systems with uncertain parameters

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering and Mining Machinery Engineering, Indian School of Mines, India
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Asansol Engineering College, India
3Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, India

author-notes.corresp: Sanjoy K Ghoshal, Department of Mechanical Engineering and Mining Machinery Engineering, Indian School of Mines, Dhanbad 826004, India. Email: sanjoy.ghoshal@gmail.com

abstract.p: This article addresses a robust fault detection and isolation procedure which is applicable for a hybrid system undergoing discrete mode changes. Global analytical redundancy relations, which may undergo change in their structure depending on the switched mode, are derived from the diagnostic hybrid bond graph model of the system. For fault detection and isolation analysis, the residuals, evaluated at every instant from the global analytical redundancy relations, are tested against adaptive thresholds which are changed with mode shift and variation of states, but not changed due to any fault. The parametric uncertainties are included in the diagnostic hybrid bond graph through the linear fractional transformation approach and the adaptive thresholds are obtained from the modified diagnostic hybrid bond graph model. The residuals are made robust in a sense that these would always remain within the upper and lower threshold bound for any perturbation except fault occurrence. For application of the robust fault detection and isolation analysis, a hybrid thermo-fluid system is selected whose behavioural evolution combines both discrete as well as continuous changes of states. It is shown through simulation that with parameter uncertainties in a hybrid system subject to frequent mode shift, robust fault detection and isolation is successfully achieved using the passive approach. The novelty of this work lies in the integration of the model-based diagnosis principle for hybrid systems with the approach for robust residual threshold generation for systems having uncertain parameters.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A dynamic system, whose behavioural evolution combines exhibition of both discrete (e.g. switches, on/off control valves, etc.) and continuous changes (e.g. compressors, electric motors, gears, etc.), is called a hybrid system.1–3 Because the system undergoes discrete mode changes, the hybrid system itself changes structurally and a separate derivation of state equations is required for every operating mode in order to model the system for subsequent model-based diagnosis.1

Many qualitative and quantitative approaches for fault diagnosis in supervision platforms are surveyed by Venkatasubramanian et al.4 Although quantitative diagnosis methods appear to be the right choice, it is often difficult to obtain proper mathematical models of complex engineering phenomena and also it is much more complicated to obtain accurate parameter values and estimates of process and measurement uncertainties. When mathematical model-based diagnosis cannot be performed, statistical approaches are used. In complex engineering systems, consistency of the diagnostic tool is very important. Therefore, many forms of diagnostic tools are simultaneously used in complex engineering systems and a voting scheme designed by accounting for the known reliabilities of individual tools is adopted to decide on the alarms and subsequent actions.5,6

Although there has been considerable research on the diagnosis of hybrid systems and the robust diagnosis of continuous dynamic systems, the literature on robust diagnosis of hybrid systems is rare.7–9 Wang and co-workers7,8 developed adaptive thresholds to avoid the possibility of false detection of mode transitions in the presence of unknown disturbances prior to the occurrence of any mode transition. Biswas et al.9 designed a diagnosis scheme for a hybrid system with a qualitative reasoning approach in the first level, and then a quantitative parameter estimation in the second stage. A statistical Z-test was employed for residual symbol generation and parameter estimation, and the approach was validated through tests on a fuel system of a fighter aircraft. Wu et al.10 designed limited look-ahead supervisory controllers for hybrid systems and experimentally validated them in a three-tank system test-bed with distributed sensor and actuation units, to test the effectiveness of the approach. Mosterman11 transformed the hybrid bond graph model into a temporal causal graph for prediction and diagnostic analyses, and applied a multiple energy phase space analysis to establish the accuracy of the models. The methodology was applied to a bi-tank system and also to a liquid sodium secondary cooling system in a nuclear reactor. Narasimhan and Biswas12 demonstrated an online model-based diagnosis methodology for hybrid systems with example scenarios generated from three- and five-tank systems. In that work,12 generation and validation of fault hypothesis were based on an algorithm performed on the temporal causal graph derived from the bond graph model undergoing mode shift. However, temporal causal graph-based diagnosis is not applicable to nonlinear systems. Those works10–12 do not address quantitative robust diagnosis for nonlinear hybrid systems with uncertain system parameters, which is reported here.

In this article, we focus on bond graph model-based13–16 quantitative robust fault diagnosis of hybrid systems with structured parametric uncertainties. Various approaches to bond graph model-based fault diagnosis have been described.17–24 To handle the discrete states, the diagnostic bond graph (DBG)18,21,22 concept has been extended to formulate the diagnostic hybrid bond graph (DHBG),1–3 which is applied to a nonlinear thermo-fluid system in this work. Exploiting the basic causality structure of the DHBG, global analytical redundancy relations (GARRs)1–3 are derived algorithmically, which can identify the fault occurrence even when the system is subjected to several mode shifts.

The method discussed here is applicable when a single parametric fault appears (abrupt, progressive or intermittent) in the system. The bond graph-based quantitative fault detection and isolation (FDI) algorithm17–21 is augmented with the inclusion of modes as variables in GARRs. In the entire analysis, the interaction of mode shift for the hybrid system and fault isolability is exposed and a case study on a thermo-fluid system is validated through simulation.

Moreover, robustness in diagnosis is particularly required with respect to parameter and measurement uncertainties22–24 so that misdetections and false alarms are both minimized. The active approach to robustness is based on generating residuals that are insensitive to uncertainties, but sensitive to faults. The passive approach tries to accomplish robustness in the decision-making stage.25,26 This is done by allowing propagation of residuals with uncertainties and then bounding the residuals within an adaptive threshold. In this article, it is shown that with parameter uncertainties in a hybrid system subject to frequent mode shift, robustness in fault detection is achieved successfully by using the passive approach.

The novelty of this research lies in the way the model-based diagnosis principle for hybrid systems is combined with the approach for robust residual threshold generation for systems having uncertain parameters. The methodology for diagnosis of uncertain systems using the bond graph model in linear fractional transformation (LFT) form is reported elsewhere.22–24 In the present work we use that methodology22–24 to develop adaptive thresholds for the residuals by considering various uncertainties in the model of the hybrid system. Two types of models for designing adaptive thresholds to achieve robustness are used. The first is the canonical form of the uncertain system state equation given as
where An, Bn, Cn and Dn are the state-space matrices using nominal parameter values; and ΔA, ΔB, ΔC and ΔD are the deviations in those matrices due to uncertainties in parameter values.

The second model is referred to as the standard interconnection model or internal feedback loop. In this form, the parameter uncertainties are separated from the nominal model and represented as feedback loops of internal variables (refer to Figure 1) as follows

where B2n = Bn, C2n = Cn, D22n = Dn; B1, D11 and D21 are the matrices for uncertain parts, {z} is an auxiliary output (internal variable), {w} is an auxiliary (internal) input and Δ is a diagonal matrix containing relative uncertainties of parameters. This model is the basic form used in µ-analysis and µ-synthesis which we use in LFT.

caption.p: Standard interconnection or internal feedback loop model.

sec.p: The bond graph representation of equation (2) may be done by defining the variations as either additive or multiplicative errors.22–24 Consequently, uncertain parts appear as modulated sources (internal feedback loop) on the nominal bond graph (LFT model in Figure 1) with certain parts.

This type of robust FDI technique using bond graphs has found application in the recent past to electro-mechanical systems, e.g. the traction system of an electric vehicle (non-hybrid), in the presence of structured and unstructured uncertainties.27 The robustness of the residuals to the considered uncertainties and their sensitivity to the faults were demonstrated through experiments. Unlike the non-hybrid system considered in Ghoshal et al.,28 hybrid systems undergo mode changes and need appropriate adaptation in each new mode. One of the problems in hybrid system modelling is the initialization of state variables at the start of every state. In this article, analytical redundancy relations (ARRs) are derived from differentially causalled bond graph models and thus these ARRs do not contain state variables. Therefore, the differential form of ARRs avoids the problems associated with the state transitions in a hybrid system.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. First, formal definitions of ARRs, GARRs and residuals are given. Then, a thermo-fluid process model having discrete modes is described along with formulation of GARRs and adaptive threshold design for robust fault detection. Some simulation studies for robust fault diagnosis of the considered hybrid system are given thereafter. Finally, conclusions are drawn.

sec.title: ARRs and GARRs
sec.p: An ARR obtained from a physical law represents some conservation phenomena: Bernoulli equation etc. in the hydraulic domain; Newton’s law etc. in the mechanical domain; and Kirchoff’s law etc. in the electrical domain. The ARRs for an ordinary (non-hybrid) system can be derived algorithmically from the derivative causality bond graph model or DBG.17–21 The bond graph model for a hybrid system with discrete mode changes is called the hybrid bond graph (HBG), and the GARRs are derived in a similar manner from the differentially causalled HBG or DHBG.

Evaluation of an ARR (or GARR) by using measurements and the process parameters is called a residual:

In this paper, a decision procedure, given in equation (3), is used for all residuals. In equation (3), each residual,

sec.title: Process and instrumentation
sec.p: In this paper, the concept of DHBG is applied to a controlled hybrid thermo-fluid two-tank system, shown in Figure 2. The two tanks (Tanki, i = 1, 2) are connected by an intermediate valve V1, Tank1 is equipped with a pump and a heater; a proportional–integral (PI) controller acts on the pump to maintain fluid level according to a specified set point and an On–Off controller acts on the heater inside Tank1 to maintain fluid temperature to specified maximum (Tmax) and minimum (Tmin) set points. Level sensors L1, L2 and temperature sensors T1, T2 are installed in the system. The On–Off controller normally works on the feedback from T1; however, in the event of T1 fault (sensor fault), the controller can be operated with the signal from T2 but with a different set point (a case of fault accommodation is shown in dotted lines in Figure 2). It has been shown by Dauphin-Tanguy et al.29 that the system would retain observability even without the sensor T1 in the present form of instrumentation. Fluid from Tank2 is discharged to the environment through a valve, V2. The purpose of the system is to provide a continuous flow of heated (but under-saturated) fluid within a prescribed range of temperature to the consumer. The atmospheric pressure is taken as reference, i.e. zero.

caption.p: Process and instrument diagram (P&ID) of the hybrid thermo-fluid process.

sec.p: The flow through intermediate valve V1 between the two tanks and outlet valve V2 to the consumer is nonlinear and controlled by the user. The Tank1 is equipped with an additional outlet to drain the liquid towards Tank2 when L1(t) is higher than LD1. The resistance RL1 offered by the drainage pipeline is considered linear. Similarly, the Tank2 drains out liquid through an outlet of resistance RL2 (linear) if the level in Tank2, L2(t), is higher than LD2. Here, for realization of switched mode operation (i.e. mode change) we impose another condition that the valve V1 (or V2) is to be controlled (changing u1 or u2) such that the level L1(t) (or L2(t)) increases above LD1 (or LD2).
The outputs from the PI controller, UPI, and the pump flow, QP, given in equations (5) and (6), respectively, are measured

The heater too has a finite response time and thus a low-pass filter is also included in the revised model of the heater. Note that such filters need not be modelled for (G)ARR derivation.

sec.title: Bond graph model of the hybrid thermo-fluid system
sec.p:
It is simpler to use enthalpy flow instead of entropy flow to model thermo-fluid systems by using the pseudo-bond graph representation. Pseudo-bond graph models for most thermo-fluid elements are detailed elsewhere,13,16 in which the vector power variables e and f are chosen as

The pseudo-bond graph model of the open-loop thermo-fluid process, in preferred derivative causality and preferred inverted sensor causalities, is shown in Figure 3, where CETF represents the Coupling Element for Thermo-Fluids.17 The constitutive relations of CETF elements are written as

Note that the temperature of the downstream side does not appear in the constitutive relations of CETF and hence the port connected to the downstream side is represented by an activated or signal bond, which carries only flow information.

Note that the mass flow f17 coming out from Tank1 through the bypass line (switched-on mode) will enter Tank2 in the same quantity, which is modelled by Sf: f17 (refer bond no. 41 in Figure 3). Along with the mass flow some enthalpy will also get transferred to the downstream side as modelled by CETF element appended to bonds 28 and 31 (Figure 3).

sec.title: Fault indicators
sec.p: The fault indicators (i.e. GARRs) are derived from the DHBG model given in Figure 3 by using the established methodology first given in Ould Bouamama et al.19 These (G)ARRs, given in equation (9), are not associated with parameter uncertainty or any other unknown inputs. So, these define the constraints in the system model under nominal operation and these are written in terms of measurements and nominal parameters of the system. Note that the measurements from the actual system will be used to evaluate these (G)ARRs to obtain the corresponding residuals. Those constraint relations in equation (9) which do not contain mode change parameters are represented as simple ARRs

The FSM constructed from the above (G)ARRs is given in Table 1, where sensor faults are not accounted for. Actuators, controllers, valves and bypass line resistances are considered as physically plausible fault candidates in the matrix.

Note that the over bar is a binary operator defined as
a

is a binary index showing monitorability or detectability of the fault in a component, and
I

is another binary index which shows isolability of the fault. From Table 1, it is seen that the heater and linear resistances RL1 and RL2 are monitorable (Mb = 1) only when they are switched on (i.e.

I

for V1. Similar reasoning is also applicable for the valve V2. On the other hand, the signatures of RL1 and RL2 either match with that of V1 and V2, respectively, during switched-on mode (i.e. Ib = 0) or the signatures are [0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0] during switched-off mode, i.e. Mb = Ib = 0. So the faults related to the parameters RL1 and RL2 are always non-isolable, irrespective of the mode status.

sec.title: Adaptive thresholds for robust diagnosis
sec.p: Adaptive thresholds are designed to achieve robustness in fault diagnosis. The robustness is particularly achieved with respect to parameter uncertainties so as to avoid misdetections and false alarms.

We have designed the adaptive thresholds using the LFT model22–24 whereby the parameter uncertainties are separated from the nominal model and represented as feedback loops of internal variables. As an example, when the actual value of a C-element is not perfectly known, it can be written as
C

caption.p: C-element with derivative causality transformed to LFT form.

sec.p: LFT forms for other elements including two ports (TF- and GY-elements) can be likewise defined.19–21 Then the DHBG of the hybrid thermo-fluid system given in Figure 3 can be redrawn in LFT form as given in Figure 6.

caption.p: DHBG model of hybrid thermo-fluid system in LFT form.

sec.p:
In Figure 6, the Df* represents the virtual sensor which measures the reactive factor of power of the pseudo source (in this case, flow for the modulated source of effort). So the outputs of the virtual sensors are basically residuals, the variations of which depend upon the uncertainty of associated parameter values within prescribed bounds. The inputs to this diagnostic model are the measured outputs from the real plant (or simulated outputs from the behavioural model as reported in this paper). All measured quantities are considered free from uncertainties. The CT1, CT2 are also replaced by their LFT form and De: T1, De: T2 are converted to MSe to obtain the corresponding residuals or (G)ARRs (if symbolic form is available), but to avoid overcrowding those are not shown in Figure 6. Again, we have considered all the sensors, controllers and actuators are robust, and always free from fault and uncertainty. So the analysis to achieve robustness in fault detection is not relevant for the corresponding (G)ARRs. Hence, the expressions for thresholds
±
ε
i
(
i = 5 ,… , 8
) are formulated for residuals corresponding to (G)ARRi (
i = 5 ,… , 8
). To derive these threshold expressions, we derive the GARRs from the DBG model including uncertainties modelled in LFT form (Figure 6) and collect the terms appearing in addition to the corresponding GARRs given in equation (9) which are derived from the nominal bond graph model (Figure 3). Note that the uncertainties in various parameters are uncorrelated. This means there is as much likelihood of them cancelling out each other as the likelihood of them adding up. Therefore, we take absolute value of each additional term in the new GARRs expressions. The expressions for the thresholds
ε
i
(
i = 5 ,… , 8
) are then given as

The upper and lower thresholds of the residuals, r5 to r8, are defined by evaluating
±
ε
i
(
i = 5 ,… , 8
), respectively, with the actual measurements, nominal parameter values and known limits of uncertainties in different parameters. The result of this evaluation,
±
λ
i
(
i = 5 ,… , 8
), gives the upper and lower bounds of residual deviations under normal operation. In addition, one may include static thresholds to account for measurement uncertainties and define the overall threshold as
±
(
λ
i
+
κ
i
)
, where
κ
i
is the static threshold. In this article,
κ
i
= 0
.

The threshold generator is a simple program that evaluates equation (12) by using the contemporary inputs (measurements), nominal parameter values and their uncertainty limits.18,22–24 To obtain the measurements, because the real plant is not available, we use a plant model and simulate it. If we use the nominal parameter values in this plant model and use its measurements for residual evaluation, then all residuals will be perfectly zero and that would prove nothing about the robustness of the diagnosis scheme. Thus, every time at the start of the simulation, we intentionally give random perturbations to parameter values and these perturbations are kept within the uncertainty limits for each parameter. For example, if
θ
n
is a parameter in the nominal model, the same parameter in the real plant model is
θ
r
(
θ
n
− δ
θ
n
<
θ
r
<
θ
n
+ δ
θ
n
)
. If measurements from this perturbed model are used to evaluate the residuals (evaluation of (G)ARRs using nominal parameter values), they will be non-zero and the residual deviations should remain within the thresholds as long as the deviations in parameters are within the assumed uncertainty limits. Any deviation above the uncertainty limit would cause the residual value to exceed the adaptive threshold and would be considered a fault. A schematic representation of the whole diagnosis processes comprising the offline and online activities is given in Figure 7.

caption.p: Overview of online and offline activities in the proposed FDI approach for uncertain parameter systems.

sec.p:
The online activities are implemented in different linked MATLAB® programs. The Simulink block diagram model of the plant with provisions for fault introduction is shown in Figure 8. The uncertainty in each parameter value is considered to be
± 2 %
. To introduce faults in the valves V1 (Cd1) and V2 (Cd2), one at a time, multiplying step functions as highlighted in Figure 8 are used. The initial and final values of the step function are given as 1 and 0.5, respectively, at a step time of 300 s, to simulate 50% valve blockage. Similarly, additive and/or multiplicative faults are introduced in other components. The lag compensator block with transfer function
( 0 . 3333
s
+ 0 . 577 ) / (
s
+ 0 . 577 )
models the response time of the heating actuator with phase lag of 30° and break frequency of 1 rad/s. The measurements or outputs (i.e. L1, L2, T1, T2) are taken from the simulated plant model and fed to the residuals and thresholds evaluation program (no simulation, just computation of residuals and thresholds as discrete intervals and approximate derivatives).

caption.p: Block diagram of the real plant model of the thermo-fluid system with provisions to introduce faults.

sec.title: Simulation of system responses
sec.p:
The system is simulated in MATLAB/Simulink with a fixed step size of 0.001 s for a duration of 600 s with all of the state variables initialized to zero. Note that a fixed step size is required to output the sampled data (measurements) at regular intervals. Computation of the derivatives of these sampled data is required in the residual evaluations and thus a fixed sampling rate is necessary. The considered nominal parameter values (arbitrary but realistic) are given in Table 2 and they are randomly perturbed within
± 2 %
limit before being input to the simulation model.

caption.p: Nominal model parameters of the thermo-fluid process.

tr.td: Set point of the PI controller
Minimum level required in Tank1 for starting of heater actuation
Height of the bypass drain of Tank1 from common datum
Height of the secondary drain of Tank2 from common datum
Maximum temperature set point of On–Off controller
Minimum temperature set point of On–Off controller
Thermal resistance to conductive heat loss from Tank1
Thermal resistance to conductive heat loss from Tank2

sec.p: The time responses of all the measurements, actuator and controller outputs, and switched modes during normal operation for the first 300 s, V1 blockage fault at a time of 300 s and persisting thereafter, are shown in Figure 9. The blockage fault in the valve V1 is realized by reducing the value of Cd1 to half of its previous value (through a step function shown in Figure 8). This deviation (50% change) in the Cd1 parameter value is much larger than the uncertainty associated with that parameter value. Note that we are assuming a single fault hypothesis which means all other parameter values remain fixed.

caption.p: Time response of outputs from sensors, actuators, controllers and switches during normal operation for the first 300 s and 50% blockage fault in valve V1 thereafter.

sec.p: From the responses shown in Figure 9, different mode (a1, a2, a3) changes subjected to different conditions are clearly visible. For example, a1 changes from 0 to 1 at time 90.132 s when the level L1 reaches the threshold value of 0.48 m, as given in the switch function. The heater becomes on when a1 = 1, and thereafter the heater follows the input control command u0 from the On–Off controller, and thus the temperatures T1 and T2 rise. Note that at time 66.908 s, u0 is on as the temperature T1 falls below 320 K, but the heater is still off because of the system not attaining the critical level of 0.48 m in Tank1, leading to a1 = 0. The mode shifting of a2 (threshold for L1 = 0.51 m) and a3 (threshold for L2 = 0.27 m) can be likewise observed.

The blockage fault in the valve V2 has also been likewise simulated by changing the value of Cd2 to half of its previous value at time 300 s. Again, single fault hypothesis is followed and all other parameter values are kept fixed. The variations of all the corresponding outputs are shown in Figure 10. The different mode changes in the system are also given in Figure 10.

caption.p: Time response of outputs from sensors, actuators, controllers and switches corresponding to 300 s of normal fault-free operation and 50% blockage fault in valve V2 thereafter.

sec.title: Fault detection and isolation
sec.p: One can conclude the occurrence of some fault(s) at the time of 300 s after due observation (monitoring) of Figure 9 or 10, but the exact faulty component cannot be localized from mere observations. As residuals are the projection of all the inputs and outputs of a given system attributed to constrained relations, one should look at the pattern in the deviation of residuals.

Because the residuals are insensitive to mode changes and are nonzero only when there is a fault, it is convenient to isolate the faulty component online by observing the signature of residuals and matching fault signatures (coherence vector) with a particular row in the FSM. At this stage, one can understand that RL1 and RL2 do not relate to any critical components of the system, as these represent hypothetical linear resistances offered by the bypass line. So, for FDI analysis, we can remove them from the FSM given in Table 1, and generate the modified FSM as given in Table 3. Note the isolability, Ib, for V2 is changed to
a
¯
2
due to the above elimination.

caption.p: Modified FSM for the thermo-fluid process.

sec.p: The time responses of residuals corresponding to the V1 and V2 blockage faults (one at a time) are given in Figures 11 and 12, respectively. The residuals r1 through r4 are zero for the whole time as we have not considered faults in sensors, actuators and/or controllers. There are no uncertain parameters involved in them and hence constant thresholds can be selected for those residuals (not shown in Figures 11 and 12). The residuals r5 through r8 are time varying and are nonzero even under normal operation due to parameter uncertainty (mismatch of parameters in real plant model and nominal parameters used for residual and threshold evaluation). The upper and lower thresholds (shown in dotted lines in Figures 11 and 12) are changing in accordance with the system behaviour during the starting transient period so that the residuals are always bounded within the adaptive thresholds under the no-fault situation. But, when the fault is imposed at a time 300 s, some of the residuals come out of their threshold bounds depending upon the respective fault signature of the faulty component.

caption.p: Variations of residuals for V1 blockage fault.
Variations of residuals for V2 blockage fault.

sec.p:
The signature of residuals after V1 blockage fault is obtained from the simulation results given in Figure 11 as [0 0 0 0 1 1 1 1], which matches with the fault signature of component V1 in the FSM given in Table 3. Hence the fault signature for V1 is validated, and whether the fault in V1 is isolated or not depends upon the status of a2. In this case, as seen from Figure 9(i), a2 = 1 after the fault inception. So,
I
b
=
a
¯
2
= 0
. Thus, although the valve V1 blockage is detected, it cannot be isolated. However, if leakage fault in V1 is simulated by increasing the value of Cd1 from its previous fault-free state value, then a2 = 0 after fault inception because L1 will drop in this case and never will exceed its threshold, resulting in
I
b
=
a
¯
2
= 1
. Thus, the valve V1 leakage fault can be both detected and isolated.

From the variation of residuals corresponding to only V2 blockage given in Figure 12, the fault cannot be isolated for a small period of time (300–391 s) when a2 = 1 (refer to Figure 10) because during this time the fault signature is [0 0 0 0 1 1 1 1], the same as for V1 blockage. However, beyond the time t = 391 s, the mode changes to a2 = 0 (refer to Figure 10) resulting in a unique fault signature as [0 0 0 0 1 1 0 1] and the fault is isolated. Thus, although one promptly detects V2 blockage fault after its inception, initially it is ambiguously isolated as either V1 or V2 fault and then it is finally revised to V2 fault. Thus, instantaneous operating modes of a hybrid system profoundly influence the ability of the decision system to monitor faults. To remove this dependence, the system needs to be instrumented with additional sensors. For example, a flow sensor in the pipe containing valve V2 adds another residual sensitive to only V2 fault and thus V2 fault can be detected regardless of the current operating mode of the system. Similar sensor placements can be worked out for other component faults.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, an FDI procedure has been applied on a thermo-fluid system which is a hybrid dynamic system containing some discrete modes in addition to usual continuous states. This is done by developing an HBG model of the system and then obtaining the DHBG model from it. The FDI analysis is based on a set of unified constraint relations called GARRs, which are derived algorithmically from the DHBG. The GARRs lead to the formation of an FSM, which exposes how the monitorability, Mb, and isolability, Ib, of different components change depending upon the mode shift.

Next, the robustness in fault diagnosis in the presence of parametric uncertainties is achieved by designing adaptive thresholds. The LFT approach is used for obtaining adaptive thresholds as a function of the system’s transient behaviour (measurements) and specified limits on parametric uncertainties. The developed algorithms have been validated through simulation performed on a thermo-fluid system, and the results suggest the viability of the quantitative robust FDI in systems with discrete mode changes. The approach presented here is not specific to any particular system and can be adapted to other dynamic systems such as mechatronic systems22 and electro-mechanical systems.27

In this paper, we have assumed small uncertainties in parameter values. If there is a small fault in the plant (say, less than 2% drift in a parameter value) then it will not be detected. Moreover, we have considered only abrupt faults. In this approach, progressive faults will not be detected until they cause sufficient drift in residuals. Measurement noise is another uncertainty which should be included in the adaptive thresholds. Furthermore, in a multiple fault situation, fault effects may cancel each other. Thus, further work is needed to address the aforementioned shortcomings.
